DisplayString.Name: JPPacks VMWare Syslog Datasource
DisplayString.Description: This data source recieves a DataItem from the built-in Syslog data source module, processes it with a powershell script using a probe action module, then maps custom parameters from a PowerShell Property Bag to a new Event's EventData using the Generic Event Mapper condition detection module. It also changes the event source to the GUID of the vCenter host which sent it.

DisplayString.Name: Collect vCenter Host Stats
DisplayString.Description: This datasource uses a pshell script to collect host cpu, memory, and datastore stats. It creates a property bag which the Write Action can use.

DisplayString.Name: vCenter Event Datasource
DisplayString.Description: This datasource collects all vCenter events.

DisplayString.Name: Discover Host Devices
DisplayString.Description: This discovery looks for ESXi hosts by looking for a SystemOID value in the collection of xSNMP.Device's of 1.3.6.1.4.1.6876.4.1. Technically this will discover any VMWare products. What I need to discover for is value of OID ".1.3.6.1.4.1.6876.1.1.0" Equals "VMware ESXi"

DisplayString.Name: Discover vCenter Clusters
DisplayString.Description: This discovery querys your vCenter server with PowerCLI and discovers Clusters. It also creates a "Hosts" instance hosted by each discovered cluster to hold the hosts discovered later. PowerCLI must be installed on your vCenter server for this discovery to work.

DisplayString.Name: Discover vCenter Datacenters
DisplayString.Description: This discovery querys your vCenter server with PowerCLI and discovers Datacenters. It also creates a "Datastores" instance hosted by each discovered datacenter to hold the datastores discovered later. PowerCLI must be installed on your vCenter server for this discovery to work.

DisplayString.Name: Discover vCenter Host
DisplayString.Description: This discovery querys your vCenter server with PowerCLI and discovers Hosts. PowerCLI must be installed on your vCenter server for this discovery to work.

DisplayString.Name: Discover vCenter Host Interfaces
DisplayString.Description: This discovery querys your vCenter server with PowerCLI and discovers Host Interfaces (vmkernels and vmnics). Both PowerCLI and the MOM Console must be installed on your vCenter server for this discovery to work.

DisplayString.Name: Discover Resource Pools
DisplayString.Description: This discovery querys your vCenter server with PowerCLI and discovers Resource Pools. PowerCLI must be installed on your vCenter server for this discovery to work.

DisplayString.Name: Discover Syslog Receivers
DisplayString.Description: This discovery looks for the following registry DWORD value: "HKLM\SOFTWARE\JPPacks\SyslogEnabled"=1. If the value is present and equals "1", this discovery rule creates an instance of the Syslog Receiver class referenced to the computer with the registry key present.

DisplayString.Name: Discover vCenter Datastores
DisplayString.Description: This discovery querys your vCenter server with PowerCLI and discovers Datastores. PowerCLI must be installed on your vCenter server for this discovery to work.

DisplayString.Name: Insert Custom Event Data
DisplayString.Description: This write action receives a single custom event property bag and writes it to the GUID specified in the received property bag. It's very similar to the InsertMultipleCustomEvents write action, and will be rolled into the InsertMultipleCustomEvents write action in a future release.

DisplayString.Name: vCenter Host CPU Average
DisplayString.Description: This monitor queries vCenter through PowerCLI for the average CPU usage of a vCenter host. It runs once per minute and collects the average CPU usage for the last minute.

DisplayString.Name: VMKernel Ping Monitor
DisplayString.Description: This monitor pings VMKernels' IPv4 addresses. Don't forget that you must add your vCenter server to all VLANs of the VMKernels that you would like to ping.

DisplayString.Name: Collect vCenter Host Stats
DisplayString.Description: Collect CPU, Memory, and Datastore stats from all hosts.

DisplayString.Name: vCenter Syslog Receiver
DisplayString.Description: Computer that is recieving syslog data.

DisplayString.Name: Insert Multiple Custom vCenter Events
DisplayString.Description: This write action receives a property bag and writes custom vcenter events. In a future release, I'd like to make this a generic custom event writer so that syslog events can be passed to it as well. This can be done by inclusing the CSV headers as the first element in the CSV string passed by the property bag.

DisplayString.Name: Insert Multiple Custom Perf Data Elements
DisplayString.Description: This write action receives performance counters as a property bag and writes them to the GUIDs specified in the received property bag.
